choices.text: Lymphocyte depleted Hodgkin’s disease
Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin’s disease

questions.text: The lymphocytic and histiocytic variant of Reed- Sternberg cell is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease

Option D:

Reed-Sternberg cells are large, abnormal cells that are characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease: In lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's disease, the Reed-Sternberg cells have a popcorn-like appearance and are surrounded by a nodular and infiltrate of lymphocytes.

Explanation:

Option A: Follicular center lymphoma: Reed-Sternberg cells are not typically associated with follicular center lymphoma, which is a subtype of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option B: In the lymphocyte-depleted subtype of Hodgkin's disease, the Reed-Sternberg cells are surrounded by a small number of lymphocytes and a significant number of histiocytes (macrophages). This variant is associated with a poorer prognosis compared to other subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option C: Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin’s disease: The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin's disease typically features Reed-Sternberg cells with a lacunar (empty) appearance, surrounded by fibrous bands.

Educational Objective:

The lymphocytic and histiocytic (L&H) variant of Reed-Sternberg cells, often called "popcorn cells," is characteristic of lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /613

questions.text: Which one of the following Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas is aggressive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Burkitt Lymphoma

Option B:

Burkitt Lymphoma is considered an aggressive Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is characterized by a high proliferation rate of rapidly dividing cells and is often associated with the translocation involving the MYC gene. Burkitt Lymphoma can occur in three main forms: endemic, sporadic, and immunodeficiency-associated subtypes.

Explanation:

Option A: Follicular Lymphoma is an indolent (slow-growing) Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma. It has a more chronic course and tends to be less aggressive compared to Burkitt Lymphoma.

Option C: Small lymphocytic lymphoma is a low-grade, indolent lymphoma that is related to chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). It is characterized by the proliferation of small mature B-cells.

Option D: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is typically an indolent lymphoma characterized by the infiltration of the bone marrow and other tissues by small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and lymphoplasmacytic cells.

Educational Objective:

Burkitt Lymphoma is an aggressive Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma characterized by a high proliferation rate and MYC gene translocation. “Burkitt lymphoma is believed to be the fastest growing hu­man tumor”…direct line

 

(Ref: Robbin 10th 598)

questions.text: Burkitt’s lymphoma is associated most commonly with of the following translocations?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. t (8:14)

Option A:

Burkitt's lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation t(8:14). This translocation involves the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) gene on chromosome 14. The result of this translocation is the dysregulation and constitutive activation of the c-MYC oncogene, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation characteristic of Burkitt's lymphoma.

Explanation:

Option B: t (9:22): is associated with Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) and Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

Option C: t (11;14): is associated with Mantle Cell Lymphoma but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

Option D: t (8:21): is associated with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) with maturation but not Burkitt's lymphoma.

Educational Objective:

Burkitt's lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation t(8;14), involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the immunoglobulin heavy chain gene on chromosome 14.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 602)

questions.text: A young boy came with dyspnea and was found to have a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is known to produce mediastinal lymphadenopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T cell Lymphoblastic ALL

 

Option D:

 

T-ALL is a type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) characterized by the proliferation of immature T-cell lymphoblasts in the bone marrow, blood, and sometimes in extramedullary sites such as the mediastinum. T-cell lymphoblastic acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is known to produce mediastinal lymphadenopathy leading to compression of nearby structures and causing symptoms such as dyspnea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is a type of B-cell lymphoma that typically presents with nodal or extranodal masses, but it is not specifically associated with mediastinal lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. B-cell rich T-cell lymphoma is not a well-recognized entity. The common types of lymphomas are generally classified as either B-cell or T-cell lymphomas.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Causes involvement of bone marrow and spleen (red pulp)

 

Educational Objective:

 

T-cell Lymphoblastic ALL  is associated with mediastinal lymphadenopathy, typically presenting with symptoms such as dyspnea due to compression of thoracic structures.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 595)

questions.text: All are B cell lymphomas except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mycosis fungoides

 

Option B:

Mycosis fungoides is not a B-cell lymphoma; it is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It primarily involves the skin and represents a neoplastic proliferation of mature T-helper cells.

Explanation:

 Option A: Burkitt's lymphoma is indeed a B-cell lymphoma. It is an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is associated with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and characterized by the translocation involving the MYC gene.

Option C: Mantle cell lymphoma is a B-cell lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of malignant B-cells with characteristic involvement of the mantle zone in lymphoid follicles.

Option D: Follicular lymphoma is a B-cell lymphoma. It is a slow-growing, indolent lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of abnormal B-cells within the lymph nodes.

Educational Objective:

Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma and not a B-cell lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 606)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with painless enlargement of a cervical lymph node. Excisional biopsy reveals a subtype of Hodgkin’s disease, which is histogenetically distinct from all the other subtypes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphocyte predominant

Option A:

Lymphocyte Predominant: This subtype is characterized by a nodular pattern with a predominance of lymphocytes and the presence of popcorn cells (Lacunar cells). Popcorn cells are large, atypical mononuclear or multinucleated cells. This subtype is generally associated with an excellent prognosis.

Explanation:

Option B: Nodular Sclerosis: Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma in the world. It is characterized by the presence of collagen bands dividing the lymph node architecture into nodules. Reed-Sternberg cells, the hallmark cells of Hodgkin's lymphoma, are found in lacunar spaces. This subtype often affects young adults and typically presents with mediastinal involvement. It has a favorable prognosis.

Option C: Mixed Cellularity: This subtype is characterized by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, including eosinophils, plasma cells, and histiocytes, along with Reed-Sternberg cells. It is often associated with an advanced stage of the disease and has a less favorable prognosis compared to nodular sclerosis.

Option D: Lymphocyte Depleted: This subtype is characterized by a scarcity of lymphocytes and an abundance of Reed-Sternberg cells. It is associated with an advanced stage of the disease and is often seen in immunocompromised individuals. Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma has a less favorable prognosis.

Educational objective:

Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s disease is histogenetically distinct from other subtypes, characterized by a nodular pattern with a predominance of lymphocytes and the presence of popcorn cells.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 613)

choices.text: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.text: Over-expression of BCL-2 proteins occurs in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Follicular lymphoma

Option B:

Over-expression of BCL-2 proteins is commonly associated with follicular lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma is characterized by the t(14;18) chromosomal translocation, which results in the over-expression of the anti-apoptotic BCL-2 protein. This translocation leads to the prolonged survival of B-cells and contributes to the pathogenesis of follicular lymphoma.

Explanation:

Option A: Burkitt's lymphoma is associated with a translocation involving the MYC gene.

Option C: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is a heterogeneous group of lymphomas and may have various genetic alterations, but it is not primarily associated with BCL-2 over-expression.

Option D: Small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) is closely related to chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and is not typically associated with BCL-2 over-expression as a defining characteristic.

Educational Objective:

Over-expression of BCL-2 proteins is commonly associated with follicular lymphoma due to the t (14;18) chromosomal translocation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 600)

choices.text: Extra nodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma

questions.text: ‘Starry sky’ appearance is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Burkitt’s lymphoma

Option A:

The "starry sky" appearance in histopathology is a result of macrophages phagocytosing apoptotic debris, creating a background of numerous small clear spaces (resembling stars) around the more densely packed tumor cells. This pattern is particularly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, which is often characterized by a high proliferation rate of rapidly dividing cells.

Explanation:

Option B: Mantle cell lymphoma does not typically exhibit the "starry sky" appearance.

Option C: Extra nodal marginal zone B-cell lymphoma is not typically associated with the "starry sky" appearance.

Option D: Chronic myeloid leukemia is a myeloproliferative disorder involving the myeloid lineage, and it does not show the "starry sky" appearance.

Educational Objective:

The "starry sky" appearance is characteristically seen in Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 598)

choices.text: Fungal infections of skin

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with persistent skin lesions, including pruritic, erythematous patches and plaques and is diagnosed with mycosis fungoides. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cutaneous lymphoma

Option D:

(Cutaneous lymphoma): Mycosis fungoides is a primary cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, meaning it is a lymphoma of the skin. It is characterized histologically by the presence of malignant T cells with cerebriform nuclei, which can form aggregates in the dermis and may invade the epidermis to form Pautrier microabscesses.

Explanation:

Option A: (Fungal infections of skin): The term "mycosis fungoides" might misleadingly suggest a fungal infection, but the condition is not caused by fungi. It is actually a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and has no infectious etiology.

Option B: (Leukemia): Leukemia generally refers to cancers of the blood or bone marrow characterized by an abnormal proliferation of blood cells. Mycosis fungoides can sometimes progress to a leukemic phase known as Sézary syndrome, but it primarily manifests with skin involvement and is not initially leukemia.

Option C: (Exfoliative erythroderma): While patients with advanced mycosis fungoides may develop exfoliative erythroderma, which is widespread inflammation and scaling of the skin, this is not the primary or sole manifestation of the disease.

Educational Objective:

Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that may present with pruritic, erythematous patches and plaques, and is characterized histologically by Sezary Lutzner cells with a cerebriform contour

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 605)

questions.text: Mantle cell lymphomas are positive for all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD 23

Option A:

Mantle cell lymphomas typically express the following markers:

Explanation:

Option B: Mantle cell lymphomas are positive for CD20, a B-cell marker.

Option C: Mantle cell lymphomas are positive for CD5, a T-cell marker. This is a characteristic feature of mantle cell lymphomas and helps distinguish them from other B-cell lymphomas.

Option D: Mantle cell lymphomas are positive for CD43, a cell adhesion molecule and marker of T-lymphocytes. It is commonly expressed in mantle cell lymphomas.

Educational Objective:

Mantle cell lymphomas are typically negative for CD23, helping to distinguish them from other small B-cell lymphomas like CLL and follicular lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/602)

questions.text: Post transplant lymphoma occurs due to proliferation of which of the following cells:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B-cell

Option B:

 ‘Post-transplant Lymphoproliferative Disorders’ (PTLDs) are lymphomas developing after solid or­gan transplantation e.g. kidney, liver, heart or lung transplants. Since the immunosuppressive drugs destroy the T cells, the patients develop B cell neoplasms more frequently.

(B-cell): Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders (PTLDs) most frequently involve B-cells. This is due to the immunosuppressive therapy administered to transplant patients which primarily affects T-cell function, leading to a relative lack of T-cell regulation of B-cell growth and the subsequent development of B-cell neoplasms.

Explanation:

Option A: (T-cell): T-cell proliferative disorders post-transplant are less common. The immunosuppression used to prevent graft rejection often targets T-cells to a greater extent, which paradoxically may result in a lesser incidence of T-cell lymphomas.

Option C: (NK cell): Natural Killer (NK) cell neoplasms are rare in the post-transplant setting. NK cells are a part of the innate immune system and are not typically involved in the pathogenesis of PTLDs.

Option D: (Monocyte): Monocytes are not commonly the source of post-transplant neoplasms. While monocytes and other cells of the myeloid lineage can give rise to cancers, such as acute or chronic myeloid leukemias, they are not the typical cells implicated in PTLDs.

Educational Objective:

Post-transplant lymphoma, or PTLD, occurs most frequently due to the proliferation of B-cells, often as a result of reduced T-cell-mediated immune regulation due to immunosuppressive therapy.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 1310)

choices.text: Anaplastic large cell lymphoma
Familial Medullary Carcinoma
Lymphocyte predominance type Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.text: Histological presence of “Hallmark Cells” with horse shoe-like or embryoid like nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anaplastic large cell lymphoma 

Option A:

(Anaplastic large cell lymphoma): Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is characterized by hallmark cells with eccentric horseshoe-like or kidney-shaped nuclei and ample cytoplasm. Many of these lymphomas are associated with a chromosomal translocation that involves the ALK gene, leading to its expression in a subset of cases (ALK-positive ALCL).

Explanation:

Option B: (Familial Medullary Carcinoma): Familial medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a calcitonin-producing tumor that arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid. It is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene but does not have hallmark cells as described in ALCL.

Option C: (Familial Neuroblastoma): Familial neuroblastoma is a rare pediatric malignancy of the sympathetic nervous system. Histologically, it shows small, round, blue cells and is not characterized by hallmark cells with horseshoe-like nuclei.

Option D: (Lymphocyte predominance type Hodgkin’s lymphoma): This type of Hodgkin’s lymphoma is characterized by the presence of popcorn cells (lymphocytic and histiocytic cells) and not by hallmark cells. It's different from the classic Reed-Sternberg cells seen in other subtypes of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Educational Objective:

The presence of “Hallmark Cells” with horseshoe-like nuclei and abundant cytoplasm is characteristic of anaplastic large cell lymphoma.

 

 

(Ref: Robbin 10th 606)

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with painless swelling of a supraclavicular lymph node. Excisional biopsy reveals a nodular pattern with a predominance of lymphocytes, and characteristic large, atypical mononuclear or multinucleated cells with a "popcorn" appearance. Immunohistochemistry shows positive staining for CD20 and CD45. What subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most likely to be diagnosed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma

 

Option A:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: (Lymphocyte depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma): This rare subtype is marked by a lack of lymphocytes and an abundance of classic Reed-Sternberg cells. It often presents in more advanced stages and has a worse prognosis. It does not typically contain popcorn cells.

 

Option C: (Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma): The most common subtype, characterized by the presence of collagen bands dividing the lymph node into nodules and Reed-Sternberg cells within lacunar spaces. This subtype usually affects young adults, and it is not primarily associated with popcorn cells.

 

Option D: (Mixed type Hodgkin's lymphoma): Also known as mixed cellularity Hodgkin's lymphoma, it is characterized by a mixed infiltrate that includes eosinophils, plasma cells, neutrophils, and Reed-Sternberg cells. It does not have a predominance of lymphocytes nor does it typically show popcorn cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A biopsy showing a nodular pattern with a predominance of lymphocytes and characteristic "popcorn" cells that are positive for CD20 and CD45 is diagnostic of Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th /613)

questions.text: A patient with lymphoma with CD10 and bcl2 marker is likely to be diagnosed with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Follicular lymphoma

Option B:

Follicular lymphoma is a B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the t(14;18) translocation involving the bcl-2 gene, leading to the overexpression of bcl-2 protein. CD10 is often expressed in follicular lymphoma and is used as a diagnostic marker.

Explanation:

Option A: Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, primarily involving the skin. CD10 and bcl-2 markers are not typically associated with mycosis fungoides.

Option C: Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive B-cell lymphoma, often associated with the Epstein-Barr virus. It is characterized by a high proliferation rate and a characteristic translocation involving the c-Myc gene. CD10 can be expressed in Burkitt's lymphoma, but bcl-2 is typically negative.

Option D: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. CD10 and bcl-2 are not typical markers for Hodgkin lymphoma. Classical Hodgkin lymphoma is more commonly associated with CD15 and CD30 expression.

Educational objective:

A lymphoma with positive CD10 and bcl2 markers is likely to be diagnosed as follicular lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/e p468)

questions.text: Lacunar cells are seen in which type of Hodgkin’s lymphoma:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Nodular sclerosis

Option C:

 

Explanation:

Option A: (Lymphocyte Predominance): This subtype is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cell variants called popcorn cells, which are usually CD20 positive, and not by lacunar cells. It has a nodular pattern and an abundance of reactive lymphocytes.

Option B: (Lymphocyte Depletion): This rare and aggressive subtype contains few lymphocytes and numerous Reed-Sternberg cells, often in a background that may include fibrosis, but not typically lacunar cells.

Option D: (Mixed Cellularity): Mixed cellularity Hodgkin's lymphoma is noted for a diverse cellular composition that includes numerous classic Reed-Sternberg cells among inflammatory cells, but not specifically lacunar cells.

Educational Objective:

Lacunar cells are a characteristic feature of the nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 618)
